etymologies: Old English ilca ‘same’, of Germanic origin; related to alike

notes.text: In modern usage, ilk is used in phrases such as of his ilk and of that ilk to mean ‘type’ or ‘sort.’ This sense arose out of a misunderstanding of the earlier, Scottish use in the phrase of that ilk, where it means ‘of the same name or place.’ For this reason, some traditionalists regard the modern use as incorrect. It is, however, the only common current use and is now part of standard English

definitions: a type of people or things similar to those already referred to

examples.text: the veiled suggestions that reporters of his ilk seem to be so good at
there was music by Parry and Elgar and others of that ilk

shortDefinitions: type of person or thing similar to one already referred to

definitions: of the place or estate of the same name

examples.text: Sir Iain Moncreiffe of that Ilk

shortDefinitions: of place or estate of same name
